er 25, 2013
												You wake up in a room with no recollection of how you got there. The last thing you know you were getting ready for bed and now you're here. A girl over the intercom tell you you're in a tower with seven floors and that you have to get to the top to get out. That's it. Oh, and by the way, you have to fight monsters and floor guardians in rhythmic RPG-ish-style battles. Are you confused yet? I was.This game features four difficulty modes and I have to admit I played this on the easiest setting, which for a rhythmically challenged person such as myself was hard enough on the last couple of boss fights. You are free to change the difficulty around in the beginning, though, since you can switch up until the third floor. The gameplay consists of fighting monsters by switching around three different 'fields'. There's a defensive, mana, and offensive field where you need to correctly push up, down, left, right according to the sequence they come down in. The trick is in juggling these three fields, since you're not able to play them all at the same time. When notes (I'll just call them that) come down in the defensive field and you miss them, you gain damage. To damage the opponent, you need to cast spells and hit the right notes in the spell or offensive field. To regain the mana you spent by casting spells, you need to go to the mana field where hitting the notes restores mana. There are quite a couple of spells in this game, ranging from healing spells to direct offensive spells to damage over time. At first it can be a bit confusing, but it does get easier over time. I personally played this game with a controller and often found myself pressing the wrong buttons when in a rush to reach the right field, causing me to miss notes. For me, the controls as such were something to get used to, but maybe it's easier when playing with a keyboard. After each battle you gain a certain amount of XP and there's the possibility of getting items. While XP is used to level Ky, the protagonist, up, it is also used as a currency. On every floor you are given a couple a recipes you can use to synthesize items, gear, and spells. In order to do so, you need to invest some XP into the synthesizing process, a little more if you want a better change of success or a little less if you want like gambling. Spells can be learned by synthesizing scrolls and then 'using' the scrolls - again, with XP. You then need to finish one of the songs with a certain percentage of correct notes or a certain combo streak. The spells learned can then be put into your ring of spells, which starts out with two slots but increases to six as you progress in the game.  Now, the music. The music was the high point of the game for me, as most of the tunes were catchy and didn't really annoy even after a reasonable amount of time spent playing. Outside of the battles I cannot recall any kind background music, though I'm sure it was there. Just not memorable. The sound effects were all right, nothing much to say there. The voice acting on the other hand I really liked. I think the characters sounded real enough, though the script was a bit of a hit or miss at times: I think the topics of conversation and references made might not be everybody's cup of tea.And last but not least, the story itself. So you start out with only knowing you need to get to the top of this tower with seven floors and that your shepherd, Naia, will guide you through via intercom. I won't spoil the story, but you won't find out much more than that until the end of the game. The ending itself, while explaining everything, felt a bit disappointing to me. If this game had relied on the story for its success, instead of the gameplay and banter among the characters, I don't think it would have worked out. All that said, I do recommend this game if only for the fact that it's so cheap and quite a lot of fun. It's not a very long game, it took me a small ten hours to complete from A to Z, but the fun to cost relation definitely says that if you're thinking of getting this game you should give it the benefit of the doubt.

												Beaten - 15 hoursBefore the Echo (or Sequence as it was formally called) is essentially a dance dance revolution/stepmania RPG.   Mechanics:- In battle, you can switch between three "dance" screens (where you match the sequences given like in DDR). Each screen is useful for one of three things: Mana, Attack, or Defense. So in order to prevent damage to you, you match the sequence on the defense screen.  You also collect items and abilities that you can use during battle.Another interestign mechanic is the game provides you "recipies" on each floor. In order to get the items needed to make something, you have to defeat an enemy. Then, to actually craft it, you get a 50% chance of success. To make it greater, you can sacrific XP 9and potentially level).  Pros:- Mechanics are fun- Music is catchy (although can get redundant)- Cool crafting system (although not terribly deep)- You can level up above the necessary requirments if you feel like it to make it easier.Cons- Can get grindy

er 6, 2014
												Very unique spin on an otherwise commonly used rhythm game mechanic.Anyone who has played rhythm games is all too familiar with the standard mechanic of having 4 columns of arrows falling in tune with the music. Sequence manages to make a very strong tactical/multi-tasking game out of it by having 3 seperate grids. One grid is the mana grid, which you use to get mana to cast spells - it's very common to miss lots of beats here in preference to landing beats on the other 2 grids. This is also where the beats primarily follow the song. Another grid is the defensive grid - beats that fall here and you don't hit will reduce your HP until you hit 0 and lose. The other grid is the spell grid. At any time you have the mana for it, you can choose to cast a spell - the effects vary from dealing damage to the enemy, healing, lifestealing, hitting the enemy with damage over time, giving yourself a mana boost, boosting the strength of the next spell you cast. Each individual spell has its own beat combination that doesn't change with the exception of inverting a few presses, left instead of right, etc, and also significant changes between difficulties. All these different spells are balanced by difficulty of input, how much blank space is there in between beats (to allow for swapping to other grids), as well as cooldown before you can cast that same spell again. Anything less than 100% on a spell input results in it failing, going on cooldown, and using up mana.All those different factors result in a very frantic level of multi-tasking that I have never seen in this genre, and continuously leaves me mentally engaged, instead of just sitting back and hitting buttons corresponding to a beatmap all day. Incredibly satisfied with Sequence for gameplay originality and engagement.Music: I'm not that big of an electronica fan, however, Ronald Jenkees has made a good effort to change my mind on that. The music for the beatmaps are all catchy. DJplaeskool did a good job with the rest of the soundtrack.Writing/dialogue: There is a large community wide disagreement between enjoyment and annoyance of the dialogue between the 2 main characters, so your mileage will vary heavily in that regard. What I can say from an objective point of view is that it is very mechanically solid, all the characters in the game have lots of personality, and the voice acting also performs just as well as the writing.Story: The story is neat and fairly original, and with an excellent great reveal at the end.RPG Elements: Probably my least favorite aspect of the game, but they work solidly enough. In order to progress to a higher level in the tower, you need to do the same 3 beatmaps on the existing level enough times to collect enough drops to craft a key to be able to start the boss fight to go to the next level. This part is just fine, since it encourages a not-excessive amount of replaying the same content to a good amount of replayability. By collecting those drops, you can also craft items that make it so your spells are stronger, you have more survivability, and/or a larger mana pool. There's also experience that gets used to improve those stats via level ups, and gets used in crafting. The big reason why I'm iffy on this, is that especially on the higher difficulties, I put myself in a dilemma of whether I just need to get less bad at the game, or if I just need to grind out some better stats to give me a better fighting chance.Overall: All the parts come to work together without any major flaws to spoil the image, and where the game truly excels is its innovative take with the 3-grid system.

content:
er 27, 2013
												I HATE rhythm games. They're tailored to those with ludicrous skills and timing and don't ever quite grasp the concept of balance very well.I don't hate Sequence because it at least tries to be a bit more generous while still failing to grasp an equitable balance of difficulty. I found most of the experience enjoyable because it's an RPG and it uses interesting mechanics so despite my implied ineptitude, I could apply strategy and grinding to bypass obstacles. It has great audio composition (being a rhythm game, I'd expect no less) and an interesting story. It alludes to a sequel that has yet to come at the time of this writing and the game's been out for some time, but I would probably enjoy it too.I played the game on the medium difficulty and found it challenging, but fun. That broke down when trying to learn the last spell where the difficulty suddenly went to extremes. Because there's an achievement dependent upon successful acquisition of this spell, I found it necessary to replay the entire game on the easy difficulty and still found myself frustrated by the difficulty leap at the same point. Even when I reached the target I was given, it still would not give me the spell because (while not indicated at all) I had to exceed the target. If you want to complete the whole thing, play on easy. If you don't mind missing the achievement and finishing everything else, play on medium. If you hate yourself and your life, there are two even harder difficulties. Enjoy!

content:
er 21, 2012
												If you are not musically challenged, you should play Sequence, it's currently the best (and only) Rhythm RPG out there. It plays like any DDR-like game, where arrows fall down the screen and you have to clear them on the beat of the music. But instead of one stream of arrows, there are three: the HP stream, where every missed arrow causes you to take damage; the MP stream, where every hit note regenerates some MP; and the Spell stream, where you have to hit every note to execute a spell successfully. The dialogue is clever, the art is gorgeous (although it uses sprites), and the item descriptions are hilarious (example: Broken Pencil [Utterly Pointless]). Best of all: it's only €3,99, and even as low as €0,99 during sales. Buy one ice-cream less this year and get Sequence.

content:
2, 2015
												This is a bit of a mixed review. The battle system is pretty interesting with the switching between screens and thinking up the best strategies to beat the enemies. I also have fun with the crafting system (but it does make the game grind-y; I find grinding rewarding so I enjoy it, but if you have little patience for that sort of thing, trying to gather all the materials and experience points to craft stuff might get on your nerves). Overall I've spent a lot of hours entertained by the game and am invested enough to want to get all achievements, craft all items, etc. So for the price I think the experience is really worth it (and I even got it on sale).That said - I expected an RPG with a rhythm game gimmick, and got a rhythm game with an RPG gimmick instead... the rhythm game battling is like 90% of the game. But it's not quite strong on its own to be what I'd call an "amazing" rhythm game... the music is a bit bland and sounds more like a nice BGM than something to actively enjoy. I also appreciate sleek visuals/designs in rhythm/music games but the battle screen looks pretty basic. This would've all been 100% fine if there was just more besides the battles to the game... like if you could actually move through a map and  meet the monsters in random encounters or something, in a more RPG-y way. Or if the story and characters were more unique and there were more and better written narration and dialogue, in a visual novel-y way. The characters are pretty basic and the dialogue is cringey at times (trying a bit too hard to be witty/funny to be taken seriously, kinda generic, uncomfortable moments like one point where the r-slur is used). Basically I feel like the game is fun but falls short of being Great. Better visuals/music, more varied gameplay, better story/writing - if it had any one of those 3 things, I think it might've been enough. I wouldn't even demand to have all three at once. But as it is, it feels like it falls short of its potential. I think the core idea of integrating rhythm games with RPG in a battle system is really great and that the game could've been better.But like I said, since it's cheap, I do think it's worth its price. So if you enjoy rhythm games you might as well get it because it'll probably provide quite a few hours of fun. If you don't like rhythm games, I'd just say you won't be missing out on much if you pass.

Good rhythm strategy music game.7.5 / 10Pros:Good music tracks.Good writing.Good voice acting.Spell setups and strategies are interesting.Highest difficulty is a decent challenge. (I recommend you play on Hard if you're even remotely familiar with the genre, as Medium is too easy.)21 Achievements.Steam card drops.Supports WASD + Arrows in combination.Key remapping.Decent art, though some enemies are simple recolors. (It's okay when it matches their spectrum stat)Smooth performance at all times.Fair game length. It took me ~10 hours to get all achievements.Option to play the tracks outside of battles, once unlocked.Crafting / Equipment / XP system is good and balanced.Hit detection is really good, even immediately after rotating fields.I got it for 99 cents.Cons:Some item drop rates will have you fighting the same enemies 10-25 times.Some music tracks are reused for other enemies.The game could use more tracks.I really wish there were more achievements to bring in more replayability. Such as getting 100% on each track while playing in "Bonus" on the highest difficulty and beating the game on the highest difficulty. Currently you can get all achievements on any difficulty.No option to change difficulty on the main menu or in "Bonus" mode. You must enter the main game, then back out.

content:
y 10
												So I really enjoyed this game but some of the mechanics and choices of the game design completely kill this game for me. First, progressing through the levels requires you to farm monster drops from the various enemies. Normally, this wouldn't be too bad but getting screwed by RNG never feels good in any game. After you finally get all of your materials to craft a key to progress, you spend experience to increase the chances that your crafting succeeds. The decision to implement F2P game design into this game is mind boggling. So after you spend all of your experience to craft your key, you end up losing levels and stats which makes you much less likely to be able to beat the boss. In a normal game you could just trust your skills to get you through the level. However, if you don't do enough damage to an enemy before the song ends then you end up losing the battle. I really wanted to enjoy this game. I really did. But the implementation of the rpg system and the horrible crafting system really made me hate it.With the bad being said, I would still have to recommend this game. Even wth all of the systems that I really dislike, the game still has me enjoying the musical gameplay while frantically switching between the different styles.TLDRPros:unique gameplaygood soundtrackCons:hate the story and characters (subjective)annoying rpg/crafting systemcan't turn up/down in game soundRNG sucksGrindyWoud still recommend even with the cons

content:
, 2014
												Sequence is a Hybrid of a Rhythm game and an RPG. Every combat is done in the way of a rhythm game like, say, Guitar Hero. With each battle you gain experience, materials and equipment, which you can all use to become more powerful, and face harder enemies, progressing through the story.That may or may not seem like it works for you, but trust me, they've done a damn fine job with it!You're Ky, and you wake up in a Tower, with amnesia. Everything inside feels like a weird game in which you're but a pawn. You life is in danger, or so you're told, and so you fight for survival, learning about the place and its purposes on the way.While the story did feel a bit cheesy for the most part, it did have a few cool ideas, and a few twists to keep it interesting. It's not the main focus on the game, but I think it added quite a lot of character to it. There's not much in way of graphic style in this one. The graphics consist mainly of hand drawn backgrounds and characters, with a bit of animation when they talk. It's not bad, by any means, just not something that you'll play this game for.Even during the battles, each spell you cast (more on that later) only produces a few sparkles as visual effects, but it's just enough not to feel empty. All in all, it's very simple, and let's you focus on the gameplay, while maintaining an appealing look. The only criticism I have of it is that certain spells will overload the screen with particles, obstructing necessary information.Another thing, regarding the interface. Outside of battle it's nothing special, but it's certainly easy to navigate. But when in-battle, it gives you every bit of information necessary without having to look for it too hard. And this is a great since, since this game WILL challenge your multi-tasking abilities (in a good way!).Good job on that! Keeping it simple, yet complete.I would now talk about the music, but music and gameplay are directly tied in Sequence. So I'll try to summarize gameplay and then talk about its strengths and weaknesses.As I said before, you're in a Tower. You're guided by Naia, who gives you recipes as you go along.You go from floor to floor, with a Boss Fight in the end of each.When you enter a floor, you'll be given recipes for Equipment, Spells, and a Key and Inhibitor for that floor. There are 3 enemies in each, which drop 3 different materials, for you to craft later. When you craft the key, you're able to unlock the door to the next floor, and fight the Guardian.Your characters has Mana (to cast spells), Health, Defense (to lower the damage you take), and Offense (to increase the damage you deal through spells).You can improve these either by leveling up, or by wearing different pieces of equipment. Equipment is mainly linear in its progression, without many sidegrades. Trinkets, on the other hand, are a bit different. These can improve your spells' cost, their cooldown, make battles harder to improve item drops, etc. These are actually more tailored for different types of gameplay, and some have pretty cool effects.Some you get by crafting, others you can get by enemy drops.The Inhibitor is used to lower the Guardians' effects (more on that later).Then, there are spells. You can craft them, and then have to learn them. How do you learn them? You play a certain track on the game, with an added challenge (which can be a note streak, or a given accuracy). These are carefuly designed, as they would be in Guitar Hero, with different button presses following the notes' pattern (to an extent, of course).They weren't too hard, mostly. But the final one was way more challenging, but also very fun to play, so I won't complain.This pretty much it for when you're outside the battles.How are the battles, then?Well, there will be arrows falling, to the beat, and you'll have to press them. Pretty simple. But that's not all, of course.(There are single notes, or doubles. For these, you have 2 sets of "arrows" on the controller/keyboard, to make it easier, specially on a controller. It works really well, and you'll find yourself a master of it by the end, and it feels great! The game does a very good way to constantly challenge you, making you better, without being frustrating.)In every battle, you have 3 screens you need to pay attention to. One, is your Defense screen. Each arrow you miss here will damage you, so you need to keep an eye on it.Another one is your Mana screen. This one has the same spell learning pattern, making it the closest to the song, with a lot more notes. Each failed note doesn't penalize you, but you gain one Mana for each note you strike, which is needed to cast spells.Finally, you have your Spell screen. You have a spell wheel, with your different spells (you have a limited number that you choose outside the battles). Each has a different effect and costs more/less mana, with a bigger/lesser cooldown.Each time you activate a spell, its notes will start dropping. The spell is cast if you strike them all. If you fail a single on, bye bye mana.That's it, mostly. Your objective is to lower your opponent's life before he does yours. Every piece of information (damage dealt, received, mana, etc.) is easily visible to you, which is great.You will be constantly switching between these 3 screens during the battles, which sometimes gets a bit chaotic at later stages, but never too bad. The whole game is a constant balance between when you can afford to take damage, when you need mana, and so on, rarely feeling stale!With each enemy is a song associated, so you'll repeat some on them quite a lot for their items/experience, but it's not too grindy.One more important aspect is the Guardians! Each one has a special ability, that'll mess you up, during their fight, and the fights in their floor. These can go from obstructing your different screens (so that you need to be there to see what's happening) to accelerating the tempo of the songs, or the last one, that switches the arrows. This one was diabolical. Everything you had learned goes to hell, and you need to play everything in reverse. But it doesn't last long, so it's all good. It's these differences that keep some of the battles very interesting, and you never know when it might throw you off of your comfort zone! The music was done by DJPlaeskool and Ronald Jenkees. It's a mix of electronic/synth music, with a bit of rock. It's wasn't something I was into at the start of the game, but it started growing on me. I ended up enjoying the music quite a bit, although I won't listen to most of it outside the game. Although, the last song, and so freaking epic... Man, I wasn't expecting that. That song had changes in tempo that worked great musically and from a gameplay standpoint! (It's called Piano Jam, search it on youtube). That one I'll be listening to for a while. Great job!So, I enjoyed the music, but I do believe it lacks a bit in replayability comparatively with other rhythm games. But it's also a very unique and very well designed game. I ended up enjoying it way more than I expected, and it had many brilliant design choices. There isn't much negative to say about it, really, aside from having to grind a bit, and perhaps looking a bit too simple. But even that didn't really lower the experience much for me.I really enjoyed Sequence, and I think it does a great job of mixing the rhythmic combat and RPG elements.One thing though, is that during the battles, while the notes do fall on the beat, there isn't as big of a connection to the notes and there is on the Mana screen (or the spell learning). Each spell has a pattern (with some random elements) that is independent of the song, and the enemies as well. So, it might not feel like like you're playing the music.But I don't think it detracts from it too much, and those modes are still present.Sequence is surprisingly great!

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
30, 2014
												Sequence is a rhythm game/RPG hybrid. Now, before you scroll past this review, hold up a sec. I never liked rhythm games either, and I'm having a blast with Sequence.Why, you ask? Well, the whole rhythm part of the game blends seamlessly with the RPG aspect. Your character has an inventory, stats and all that RPG jazz (though no choice and consequence so it's not a REAL RPG!), and from his equipment and statistics come his fighting abilities. Ky (the hero) fights with spells, casting them at his enemy if you input the correct rhythm sequence. He also has to defend and regain mana, also done by inputting the correct rhythm. Now, while he's casting spells, he can't defend or regain mana, unless you quickly switch screens during your rhythm input, a tactic which is unnecessary in the beginning but becomes more and more vital as the game goes on, and spells start to have pauses between their prompts.This whole combination of RPG and rhythm game is brought with wonderful humour. Don't expect silly puns, lazy groaners or pretentious in-jokes, the game just approaches everything with a healthy and snarky brand of humour, from the dialogues to the item descriptions. Of course, since it's a rhythm game, the music is a very important element, and it doesn't disappoint. You'll hear a lot of it, but it never bores. The composers enlisted by Iridium to score the game have done a great job, and all the music is extremely engaging to listen to.Again, don't be surprised if you find yourself gnashing your teeth at the screen in the beginning. Once you learn to correctly input the prompts by listening to the music, instead of visually, you'll find it becomes a lot more manageable and you'll improve in leaps. And once that happens, you'll have awesome fun with it!

ry 16, 2014
												Similar to Stepmania and Dance Dance Revolution but entirely unique in its own way. Sequence offers an entirely new idea to the practice of pressing arrow keys by utilizing three different windows for different game mechanics. These include The Attack window where you can ready your attack against your foe, The Defense window allowing you to nullify your opponents' attacks, and the all important Mana window with the ability to regenerate mana, which is used to cast spells.The game includes an emotive storyline which will lead the player through he many mysteries that await the protagonist and his 'Shephard'. While keeping the modern-day theme, Sequence maintains a healthy dosage of humour whilst keeping al seriousness intact.When I played this game the music amazed me, it's hard to believe that a game can have so many good soundtracks, and with the game costing so little it's a wonder why more people don't buy it simply for the music. I give this game a 10/10 for originality.

content:
10, 2015
												You juggle three separate beatmania windows (defense, spell casting, mana regen) in a story like tetris attack.And now time for me to take a ♥♥♥♥ on this game and explain why it's bad. There's a drop system, but you almost only get ingredients--which means there's a craft system. The only way to get the keys you need to acess the next level of eneimes and progress in the game is to hope the levels drop the ingredients you need and THEN hope you succeed in crafting. Every time you craft you sacrifice your exp (INCLUDING LEVELING DOWN) and here's the kicker: you can fail to craft, which will expend the exp regardless. It almost sounds absurd how badly this game wants to eat your time while pretending it's fun. If time is money then this game is on the same level as those horrendous microtransaction modeled games. The poorly voiced dialouge is littered with social justice warrior overtones (I wish I were joking), and since all your fights are timed you'll end up wanting or needing to grind levels to hit harder faster. OH WAIT I SPENT MY EXP AND LEVELED DOWN BECAUSE THE RNG REFUSED TO CRAFT PROPERLY. Don't worry though, you can increase your chances to craft successfully by.........spending more exp per attempt.Uninstalled, I regret spending money on this ♥♥♥♥ fest.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 6
												The mashup of RPG/rhythm is very cool, and switching between the different aspects of the battle is a great idea.  That's where my praise of this game ends.In one of the worst openings to any game I've ever played, we are immediately subjected to terrible dialogue with worse voice acting.  Every line is delivered awkwardly and with a shoehorned-in joke.  The writer goes out of their way to try to poke fun at RPG/gaming stereotypes, and not a single joke lands.  If that wasn't bad enough, we're subjected to approximately 20 minutes of tutorials before we can even play the game.  A character even calls the game out on having too many tutorials, which begs the question why this was not fixed prior to release.When we finally get to play the game, we find that we're in for a repetitive, non-stop grind.  Let's go through the steps it takes to learn a new spell:  1) grind multiple battles against one or more enemies. 2) craft the spell, which may fail, requiring repeat of step 1. 3) learn the spell, requiring you to play a mini-game, which is a more boring version of a regular battle, oh and by the way the song is the same song you heard 6-7 times during step 1.  What should be an exciting aspect of an RPG (learning a new spell, oh boy!) is instead reduced to a slog.  And that, in a nutshell, is Before the Echo.Stay away from this one.

ry 20, 2012
												Sequence is probably the first game ever that has combined a rhythm type game with RPG. Make no mistake this is an indie game, the rhythm feature is rather lackluster and the watered down RPG leaves a lot of be desired. The developers claim that this game should take you 12 hours, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. It will take you 6 hours max to beat this game if you skipped item farming. Combine item farming with the rather limited collection of music and you are in for one hell of a repetitive ride. Luckily this game makes up for all of its errors with its impressive voice acting; the various bosses you meet have various distinct personalities that make them super memorable. The game presentation is also very beautiful and organized. The music, although limited, is ridiculously catchy. Finally the game base price is five dollars that alone negates every negative thing said about this game! Go buy it and promote creative indie development.

content:
ry 7
												As someone from the DDR generation, it takes a lot for a rhythm game to receive a good review from me. Keep that in mind when reading this review.Before the Echo is a very interesting approach to the genre. It combines RPGs and rhythm. During the game you equip your character with various equipment and spells and fight monsters.Fighting monsters is accomplished by toggling between a magic, defense and mana field and trying to hit the arrows at the proper point. You will frequently find yourself choosing between recharging your mana, defending against enemy attacks, and using magic against the enemy.This combat approach is very well implemented when using a controller. They obviously put a lot of thought into it, and it makes sense. The music is fine. It didn’t stand out as anything special to me. I didn’t really “feel” it though, so it was more a matter of watching the arrows than listening to the beat. This can probably be improved by ensuring your audio settings are correct. I have mixed feelings about the tutorial and plot. The tutorial accomplishes its purpose well, after playing through it, you know how to play the game. The plot consists of waking up in a tower, having a snarky/sarcastic woman tell you what is going on, and then fighting monsters to get a key to move to the next floor. I don’t know more than that, as the game quickly lost my interest. I was very glad we have the ability to skip the plot scenes. I found the character’s interactions very annoying. Despite being well designed, the game didn’t grab my interest. It felt like it was missing something. It is inexpensive enough that fans of the genre might as well give it a try, but casual players should look elsewhere.

content:
23, 2014
												Wow. Sequence, we've got a lot to talk about.Sequence is basically a DDR/ITG + RPG mashup, which may sound odd, but it works pretty fluently. Even as someone who's been an avid fan of the four-arrow dance games for over a decade, it took me a while to get fully accommodated with Sequence's unique gameplay.However, one thing I certainly did not expect from a game like this was a compelling plot with brilliantly well-written and fully voiced characters. Sequence's story gives the game a lot of depth and was probably the driving factor for me. Definitely a huge highlight of this game.I could nit pick for quite a while, though. The music isn't anything extraordinary, it can be a bit grindy at times (as both item crafting and item drops are chance based), and the battle interface could use a little bit of work to make it easier to see what spells are ready, what the mana cost is, how much you have at the time, etc. Since I played with the keyboard, having all the tutorials and controls based around a 360 controller was also a tad confusing.Sequence is pretty fun and I would recommend it to rhythm game/RPG fans or people who enjoy a really good story.

content:
r 18, 2014
												Oh dear God I love this game. This is a really addictive and difficult (On hard difficulty at least) rhythm RPG. You have to switch between three panels, each of which you can see in the background even if you're not using them. The defence panel is to stop attacks that enemies throw at you, any missed will cause you to take damage. The spell panel comes up with the rhythm of any spell you cast, and missing even one will cause the spell to fail. Finally, the mana panel has rhythm which fits the song and replenishes the ability to use spells. Very difficult to keep track of the three, yet whenever you mess up you KNOW it's your fault. It also lasts a fair amount of time, however the necessary random drops can be quite frustrating. ALWAYS make all items you can on a floor, they will be needed.

												One of the best rhythm games out there. Combines an awesome soundtrack by Ronald Jenkees with very unique and fun gameplay. You have 3 DDR-like "boards" playing at the same time, one where enemies deal damage to you if you miss the notes, one that you can miss that lets you build mana, and one that only starts playing when you have a spell to cast. The game includes RPG elements in the form of item drops and crafting (which gets you more spells and more ways to get an advantage over enemies). Also has some nice art, decent story and entertaining characters. Would definitely recommend for its current price.

number of helpful: 5 of 12 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2015
												Before the Echo (formally sequence) is a game with many good ideas.  This is a shame, because it buries them in terrible design and writing.Let's start with the good.  The basic gameplay of the game revolves around a rhythm based combat system. This is similar to DDR or Stepmania, but with three step charts (one for your attacks, one to defend, and one to recharge your mana).  This system is intuitive and rewards both musical ability as well as strategy (primarily for when you attack).  If this game was just a series of songs which had to be defeated using this system it would have been great.Unfortunately the game has been lengthened with the most obnoxious forms of grind.  To get to the next boss fight and to proceed to the next area, you must craft a key.  To get the items for crafting the key you must fight the three monsters on your level.  They have a random chance of dropping various items, with some of the required items having a very low chance to drop.  And on top of this, crafting isn't guaranteed.  You can sacrifice your XP (and possibly lose levels) to increase the chance of success, but the success rate caps out at 95% so you can still fail.  If you do fail you lose everything and have to repeat your hunt for those items from scratch.This means that the game very quickly forces you to repeat the same fight over and over and over again, long after it has ceased to be challenge anymore.  This completely killed any enjoyment I had for the game.  I have a feeling the developers added these grind elements to lengthen the amount of time that people would play the game, but it had the opposite effect for me.While the grinding aspects are what kill this game, I should note that the writing is also horrible.  Absolutely everything in the game, from the dialogue of every single character and every single item description, is written in this ironic hipster tone.  This might have been amusing if it had been done in moderation, but as it is every bit of text in the game is trying to show you how funny it is, when very little is even amusing (unless you find lines like "I feel like my brain got stabbed by a hobo" to be hilarious).  It also kills your sense of immersion when absolutely every character is aware (and comments on the fact) that the game mechanics don't make sense and seem to be completely artificial.

												This is an extremely fun game. Just like how Puzzle Quest: Challenge of the Warlords introduced RPG elements to make Bejeweled better (and succeeded), the introduction of RPG elements to the music game genre made it better as well. Grinding is a little tedious, since each monster you fight has one specific song they use, and you will need to fight it multiple times to get all the items necessary for crafting, but with only a few exceptions, the songs are ALL good. The game is stable, the art style is pretty cool, and the voice acting is funny at times. It's easily worth $5, especially if you like music games.

content:
y 14, 2014
												I love rhythm games. Stepmania used to occupy all my time when I was younger, but this game is just so messy. Casting spells then waiting for them would create awful timing where you'd end up having to defend yourself by the time your spell appear, so you'd have to stagger your timing, and failing a spell will punish you with reallocating your timing between attacking and defending to regenerate your mana. To make it worst, each fight is a timelimit based on the song's length so if you get to a choppy start, you're pretty much screwed. Timing is everything with rhythm games and for me there's just too much to keep track for me to enjoy actually playing the game.Plus, this game is a pain in the ♥♥♥ if your play style involves two hands.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2015
												As a huge fan of Rhythm games and RPGs I thought that this game would be amazing, but I am extremely disappointed.While I ultimately ended up playing on Spasmodic difficulty, and am capable of getting 100% on several songs when I 'practice' in the bonus mode, the RPG elements, coupled with the field switching mechanic makes many foes extremely challenging.Speaking of RPG elements, there is absolutely no explanation of the actual mechanical effects of the offense and defense stats. It's logical to assume that defense decreases the damage you take from missed gems, which is in turn multiplied by the gem color, but no indication is given about how much defense reduces how much damage.Coupled with the fact that you can't see actual concrete stats from enemies (only vague bars), and the RPG mechanics seem to be a gimick that was tacked on to a rhythm game to make it 'harder' without requiring them to add more songs or harder difficulties for the songs.Ultimately, I'd rather play something like Stepmania on the harder difficulties for my Rhythm game fix, and then play an RPG like Dragon Age or one of the various Elder Scrolls.I give this game a 2/5. I might have given it a 3/5 purely for the snarky dialogue during the cutscenes, but the audio quality is hit and miss. (You can tell that certain lines were recorded on different days when the ambient sound changes)

content:
er 29, 2011
												I really have to amend my previous recommendation.   This game is good, but it's not as great as I thought it would be.  The lack of RPG elements beyond combat and item use really kind of hobbles the game. This would be great if it fell back heavily on the rhythm game aspect of the game, because that genuinely shines.  The problem is, there are only a very small handful of songs.  Very small.   Each area, you don't get random encounters, you get a small stable of enemies to CHOOSE from.  Combat gets you items to combine into the key that gets you to the next area.  You will fight these same enemies over and over until you get the drops you want, playing through the same light airy techno/electronic music over and over.  The artwork is beautiful, if amateurish (it looks like it's hand painted by someone's really artistic friend), and the dialogue is fan-♥♥♥♥ing-tastic, and delivered very sarcastically and deadpan.  But this doesn't stop the actual gameplay from getting really tedious.

content:
y 19, 2014
												So I got this game for like 50 cents.  It's marked at 5$, so I'm going to treat it like it's a 5 dollar game.It's not worth 5 dollars.  Want a decent 5 dollar game?  Check out Knights of Pen and Paper, or when you grow a sack get X-Com UFO Defense.So why isn't this game good?  I've played tons of rhythm games and this one has 'decent' music, but has no real assemblence of something you could nod your head to and say: yea, this works in a rhythm game.  It simply doesn't and the input is bad.  Now to meet anyone that says: maybe you're just bad at rhythm games, maybe I am, but I the music alone is not motivating and doesn't telegraph much of a downbeat let alone figuring out the count.The game tries extremely hard to be hip and ironic.  Using references of date ♥♥♥♥, crystal meth, and getting stabbed by a hobo in less than 1 minute to get you to say: YEA, THIS IS HIP!It's a huge grindfest that just wares down compared to other grind games [like Knights of Pen and Paper].  You have to find items by selecting monsters to fight, then craft items from those items found, but you have to spend xp to increase the rate of success.  If you fail, everything you bid is lost and you have to go back to the half-hazardly made ACID-Pro electronic music.It's 5 dollars, sure, but it's not at all worth that.  There's so much this game attempts to do that sounds really cool!  [That Bejeweled RPG game series that came out a few years back was actually cool!] This game is not!  It has a lot of things it's trying to do, but all of them are executed poorly.  If anyone can get through this rhythm game and say 'yea this music guides me', then you have an ear I simply do not possess.  The game even says, listen to the music not so much watch the arrows.  If you listen to the music, it will throw you off!  I muted this game and aced every monster I came across.The music is 'good', but it's not good for rhythm based games.

content:
17, 2014
												At first glance, this game is a unique rhythm and battle game. I would enjoy this IMMENSELY more if there were multiplayer. Fighting against stale AI is pretty dull, but I like it for what it is. The dialog is full of excruciatingly bad deliveries of unwitty jokes and poor "insightful" satirical sarcasm that belittles people's intelligence in an almost superfluously verbose manner (as if they are talking to a child). I don't need the explanations of these poor attempts at "correcting" whoever they are trying to correct and I am sure most people didn't eg., when they say the word "Mana" and say it is pronounced "Mah-na", It came off so pretentious and belittling. It would just be so much better if they didn't have this unnecessary dialog for the tutorial, people want to get straight to the gameplay and see if they like it before wasting an hour of dialog! I know how "Mana" is pronounced, I am sure most avid gamers are familiar with it and even MTG players. BUT the MAIN character, I guess because of the personality he was given? He speaks FOR me. He called Naia annoying, dear god is she annoying! The voice actor who did her, I don't know if it was a girlfriend of one of the developers or something, but she has that valley girl voice that makes me want to rip my hair out every time I hear her vocal fry. She stutters here and there and fails to convey her credibility as a "guardian" in the game. Despite her lines and voice acting being terrible, the main character proves a redeeming glimmer of hope of tolerance. Being there were some sound issues already, I expect way more and some of the sfx are not mixed into the overall game volume very well. The music, thus far, is pretty bland. It would be better if they were all original tracks catered to the players and developers. I recommend the game if you can catch it on sale or in a bundle or if you have a 10-16 year old sis/bro, otherwise I'd say to go find a different rhythm game. If multiplayer comes to be in this concept, then it's on!

content:
r 22, 2011
												Played this for a little more than 30 minutes and it's not what I expected. I expected an RPG with rhythm based combat, like it actually advertises. But it falls short on every level, except for the music. The music is actually something that I enjoyed listening to. The graphics are very basic; the art looks ok, but there are basically no animations. It feels very empty and simple. I'll admit I can't expect a 'retail quality' game for this price, it's true. But still, if you build expectations you better deliver.The combat is a nice idea, but poorly executed. You pick an enemy from a list (I know, right?) and then fight it by pressing buttons on the beat of the music. It's nothing fancy, and about everything is text based, items included. You explore the tower by picking levels from a list as well. Wait, what?There's just no style; it doesn't stand out. There are some cool ideas in it, but like I said, it's really, really poorly executed.Sorry guys, it's not worth the money.[Rating: 69/100]

												This game is regular rhythm game with small extra gimmicks but little content.In this game, like in other rhythm games, you press different keys (in this case arrow keys) in the rhythm of music. The extra gimmick of this game is that you simultaneously fight against monster and there are different rhytm lines for Mana, Attack and Defence. See some videos about this, if you want to know more as I am not going to explain this further in this review. This little gimmick is not bad, but it isn't revolutionary either. In the end the game is extremely bland and for a person like me who isn't fan of this kind of genre, the game was waste of time excluding funny conversations that the characters make in the story that gave some delight. What makes me not to recommend this game is that it is very repetitive. There is only a few of songs and the gimmick that this game has is seen very quickly.Grade: 5/10I would only recommend this to a person who is fan of this genre and who has tried all other variations of this kind of games.Last edit was to change Grade from 4 to 5 to be more in line with my other reviews.

y 3, 2015
												Wow. Where to start?The controls are bad. First time I played it detected my pad and therefore forgot to mention the keyboard keys which I had to find on my own (and you have to rebind them cause they are stupid. Try using the up and low arrows quickly at the same time for example).Second they are not responsive. I've played rythm games before and never had any problems (especially at lower difficulties).Third. The story is non existent, the dialogs are terrible and probably made for 13 year old kids.The voices are so bad it hurts.Fourth the music is bad. It's not electro it's not techno, it's closer to elevator music.Fifth I'll be having nightmares about this game.Sixth first time I'm writing a review but I felt I had to. (Can't believe there are so few negative reviews about that game).

r 15, 2012
												8/10This is the good ol' dance pad game, except you use your keyboard or controller (recommended) to push the right buttons at the right time.You have 3 different... let's call them "beat displays":One is for mana (which you need for your attacks or for healing yourself), one is for your attack/s and one is for blocking the enemy's attacks.The story is the average "You wake up in a strange place, want to get out of there and have to play by the rules of your abductor" one, but it's still interesting and funny.Conversations between the main character and NPCs sometimes refer to websites like ♥♥♥♥♥ and YouTube, memes like "That's what she said" and "Yo dawg..." and sometimes they even make jokes below the belt you might have heard before.The game's soundtrack is quite repetitive, but it has a lot of good tracks that are worth it.You like playing with music? Get it.

content:
5, 2016
												When I was a kid, I really liked DDR.  I bought this game because I thought it would be like DDR.  I am disappointed that this game is not a whole lot like DDR.I'm having trouble separating my disappointment of this game as a scratch to my DDR itch and how I feel about the game as its own thing.So first I have to say, if you want to buy this game because you're like me and want to scratch that itch, give it a pass.  The objective of this game is to miss a bunch of notes on purpose, which drives me absolutely insane.  Just watching arrows pass by without being pressed.By itself?  I dunno, it's got a lot of cringey humor and some mediocre voice acting.  The RPG elements seem kind of compelling?  But also really confusing?  It just feels really unpolished, I had a lot of trouble grasping how well I was doing because the visual feedback is less than great.  I think, mechanically, this kind of step rythm game just wasn't meant to be mixed with an RPG.

4, 2014
												TL:DR - One of the most unique $5 gems you can pick up. Definitely worth checking out.Sequence is a game I strongly enjoyed playing not because of its music, art-style, or its plot, all of which are really well done. It's the unique gameplay that Sequence carries. Yes, on first glance, it's like Dance Dance Revolution. However it's unique because you play three different windows that you can switch to at any time. One window is for defense, one is for regaining MP, and the other is for spells you cast. I kind of feel like a music mixer by switching between these three windows constantly and hitting several notes.The thing that also makes Sequence shine is the fact that it has so much potential in its core game that it's one of those few games out there that could spawn a successful sequel if it wanted to! It's also a quick game (took me 7-8 hours to 100% the game on normal difficulty, maybe another hour or two to get the rest of the achievements) with lots of replayability in the other difficulty levels. It's only $5 too!

2, 2012
												Imagine playing DDR with your hands and managing three machines at the same time.  That is pretty much the core of this game.  If you like rhythm games that consist of four directions, you might like this.  Essentially, you're juggling three DDR boards, but it's not like there's constant arrows (it does get harder, mind you).  One board is like charging up your mana.  One board is strictly for inputting attacks.  The remaining board is to defend against enemy attacks.Oh, and I think there's a story here, too, but nobody cares.

er 28, 2013
												A fantastic game in which all of the mechanics have been honed to perfection. The DDR Max-RPG hybrid system works flawlessly, the voice acting is top notch, and the dialogue is great. Little touches such as being able to spend experience points to increase synthesis success, having a practice mode to work on your timing, and more are all done well. The hand painted enviornments look gorgeous, and the character and enemy designs are great, although a couple of the later enemies are palette swaps of the early ones. The soundtrack is great, with several catchy songs you'll find yourself humming in the shower later. Unfortunately, the number of tracks is rather limited, and each enemy is assigned only one song, but the songs are still good enough that they don't get annoying. The only flaw I can find is that there is no free play mode, as at this point I have reached such a high level that even the hardest battles only take around thirty seconds to win. Still, its hard to fault a game for not letting you replay it enough, so I'll conclude by saying that this is the single best indie title I have had the pleasure of playing on Steam. A fantastic game that should be enjoyed by all.

												So like you're this guy named Ky and you wake up in a tower of power wondering where the hell you are. Suddenly, a voice rings out and it's from a girl named Naia, who is pretty chill but willing to sass Ky whenever he acts like a nerd (which is often). She teaches him how to harness the power of DDR-like magic in order to defend himself because if he doesn't, then he ends up dead. Being dead is pretty bad, so try to avoid that. As Ky climbs up the tower, he runs into weirdoes who possess the power to screw with his playing field in increasingly annoying ways. There's a lot of puns, references, and wordplay in the game, which can be a dealbreaker if you're some scrub who can't deal with it/ignore it. You, the player, must guide Ky in his journey to find out who put him in the tower, why he's there, and who Naia is.

er 30, 2013
												Sequence is a rhythm RPG, which is, in and of itself, an interesting concept. It delivers this with surprisingly unique gameplay, an interesting story, and an excellent, albeit limited, selection of music to play along to.In terms of gameplay, it's not unlike DDR in that you have four arrows that you have to hit to the rhythm as they reach the bottom of the screen while music plays in the background. However, the similarities stop there. Combat involves rotating between three screens: your damage screen, your mana screen, and your spell screen. The damage screen represents incoming attacks from your opponent, and each arrow missed on this screen will result in your health taking a hit. The spell screen is used for all of the abilities in the game, where you must select what type of spell you want to perform and then hit every arrow in that spell for it to succeed. The mana screen grants mana, for casting spells, with every arrow that is hit. As a result, the game turns into a very interesting experience where you have to time spells so that you don't take too much damage, and prioritize each of these screens so that you can keep yourself alive and deplete your enemy's health bar before the song ends.When a battle concludes, loot is dropped. This loot can be used to craft specific items on each floor, such as new weapons and equipment, a key to get to the next level, and a few other secrets that are best observed within the game. Especially towards the end, there are some very interesting items that can be crafted, and a lot of secrets and hidden content. I highly recommend crafting every item in the game, waiting until after the credits, and then exploring a bit more based on what you learn. This game quickly becomes intriguing, and knows how to deliver on it.One point of criticism I have for this game is that, if you're looking to craft all of the items in the game, it can get a little repetitive. Each enemy has the same song every time you fight them, and when you get close to the end, there are a few items that have pretty low drop rates. Having to repeat the same fight fifteen times in a row, as a result, can get a drab. Luckily, it's not the exact same pattern of arrows every time, and the gameplay is engaging and fun enough that I didn't find this to be much of an issue, but it is something worth mentioning.If you're a fan of rhythm games, Sequence brings a twist on a traditional formula that makes it feel almost entirely new. I'm glad I put in all of the time that I did, and I think a lot of people would be surprised at how much they enjoy it.

, 2012
												Puzzle Quest is to Bejeweled as Sequence is to DDR. Sequence is a dungeon crawler / RPG of sorts in which battles are done in DDR-like matches. Of course, arrows are hit with keys instead of a dancepad. The twist is that there are three different playing fields, and you have to switch between them. One regains mana as you hit notes, one blocks incoming damage when you hit the notes, and one is for casting spells. It's an interesting concept, and while it's done very well, it still seems to be amateurish. I'm glad I played it for a bit to get a good idea of the game, but it's not worth the grinding to continue.

18, 2012
												An extremely novel idea executed very well. The story is so-so, and the voice acting feels like it was done by bored devs, but the gameplay and audio really make this a win. It is a mixture of a rythm game and an RPG, which pits you against an oppenent to music where you must hit notes on your gamepad/keyboard in rythm on one of 3 boards to win. 1 board gains mana, 1 casts various spells, and 1 defends on attack. Balancing which spells you take into fights, which boards you focus on, and handling the special abilities that bosses throw at you is a lot of fun. It doesn't hurt that the musical selection is also very good.

17, 2012
												Interesting concept with the 3 different screens of arrows you have to switch through.  Tries very hard to be an 'offbeat RPG' like Puzzle Quest, but ultimately the RPG elements are unimportant and the story sequences feature a bunch of flat and emotionless voice actors trying to be hip and witty.If fanboys of the Matrix got together and tried to film another Matrix with no budget and an all-new script they wrote themselves, the dialogue would probably sound like it does in this game.  It's painful.  If you watch the trailer and listen to one of the devs trying way too hard to be hip while describing the game, you'll understand why it turned out this way.Sadly the music is a low point as well.  You would think in a game built entirely on timing, music and rhythm that the audio tracks would be a high point, but all of these tracks feel like recycled DDR tunes.If at some point in your life you *really* enjoyed finger DDR or Stepmania, you might like this game.  Otherwise, skip it.

												As someone who loved stepmania and was addicted to it for a long time this game feels right at home. The game includes some great soundtracks, and it was sad defeating an enemy early just because the song would end early. The audio goes perfectly with the visual aesthetics of the game  and the artwork is truly stunning.There is some farming involved in progressing through the game but if you play any RPG this is nothing out of the ordinary.Over all it is unique and lots of fun. great music and highly addictive.

												If you like rhythm games, this game is for you. You may satisfied playing Stepmania or Guitar Hero or what have you, but this is the real deal. It'll fill the void in your heart you didn't know you had.Someone took a very good RPG, ripped out the battles and replaced with a dancing game and novel mechanics. This is a game within a game, and the developers nailed both of them. The visual novel style is not my type, and the game could have better replay value, but those flaws are compensated by the great story and solid gameplay.

												TL:DR - One of the most unique $5 gems you can pick up. Definitely worth checking out.Sequence is a game I strongly enjoyed playing not because of its music, art-style, or its plot, all of which are really well done. It's the unique gameplay that Sequence carries. Yes, on first glance, it's like Dance Dance Revolution. However it's unique because you play three different windows that you can switch to at any time. One window is for defense, one is for regaining MP, and the other is for spells you cast. I kind of feel like a music mixer by switching between these three windows constantly and hitting several notes.The thing that also makes Sequence shine is the fact that it has so much potential in its core game that it's one of those few games out there that could spawn a successful sequel if it wanted to! It's also a quick game (took me 7-8 hours to 100% the game on normal difficulty, maybe another hour or two to get the rest of the achievements) with lots of replayability in the other difficulty levels. It's only $5 too!

												At first, this looks like a simple arrow-rhythm game and some RPG bits with a story thrown in. But then you start playing. The arrow-rhythm game is actually combat against a monster, with 3 screens, your spells (which decide when to trigger) defense (occasional arrows), and mana recovery (pretty much constant arrows). You jump back and forth between these 3 screens, juggling the 3 purposes. The progress of the RPG bits feel solid though not spectacular. But the story is just absolutely amazing. The pacing is perfect, with a few twists and an ending that ties back to the very beginning.

												So like you're this guy named Ky and you wake up in a tower of power wondering where the hell you are. Suddenly, a voice rings out and it's from a girl named Naia, who is pretty chill but willing to sass Ky whenever he acts like a nerd (which is often). She teaches him how to harness the power of DDR-like magic in order to defend himself because if he doesn't, then he ends up dead. Being dead is pretty bad, so try to avoid that. As Ky climbs up the tower, he runs into weirdoes who possess the power to screw with his playing field in increasingly annoying ways. There's a lot of puns, references, and wordplay in the game, which can be a dealbreaker if you're some scrub who can't deal with it/ignore it. You, the player, must guide Ky in his journey to find out who put him in the tower, why he's there, and who Naia is.

y 1, 2012
												Rhythm game meets old-school turn-based RPG. This is every bit as peculiar as it sounds. The music is slick, much of it licensed from capable hands such as the wonderful Ronald Jenkees, and the gameplay can be quite punishing on higher difficulty levels. I would recommend playing this game witha controller, and indeed have not checked if it is possible (or enjoyable) without.You'll be switching between three sets of scrolling DDR style arrows: one for incoming damage that is blocked by accurate hits, another (typically containing the most difficult pieces of the song) recharges your Mana pool on accurate hits, and a third for spells. Spells are cast with the right analog stick, which (after a delay) sends down a specific rhythmic snippet that changes it's tempo to fit the current song (the specific direction of arrows changes every time you cast, and the difficulty level also changes the spells, making the more complicated versions of the same basic rhytmic idea). The game has you madly flying between these screens to defeat enemies before the song ends--it's one wierd, wild ride and it's well worth it. Battles are tense and fascinating, and there's a lot of room for varied play styles in your spell collection of choice as well as a lot of room for growth within the broad difficulty span. There's even a practice mode where you can just play through the full songs in a more standard rhthym game format. Highly recommended.

y 30, 2012
												If you're a Stepmania and/or DDR addict, I won't recommend this to you, cause you already own this game.For those of you not quite as addicted to keyboard-dancing: Sequence pardon me, 'Before The Echo' (lawsuit trolls forced them to change the name) is a rhythm game, but with a catch--and added RPG elements. The controls can take some getting used to, especially because a certain kind of multitasking is required of you in all battles, but you'll quickly pick them up. They're fully customizable to suit your own preference--which you will be glad for, as the highest difficulty will have you crying for mercy at times. That said, there is something incredibly satisfying about the combat system, and that certain something is what has made me return to this game multiple times, eventually beating it on the hardest difficulty setting with no little satisfaction.Gameplay aside, Sequence Before The Echo manages to weave in a nice story with likable characters, with some of the most natural-sounding dialogue I've heard in years. I loved its sense of humor, found everywhere from dialogue to item descriptions. Without spoiling anything, the ending had me both widening my eyes and laughing at the same time.The music is above-average, as it should be for a music-based game. Some songs are better than others, and there's definitely a few earworms in there.Long story short: why haven't you put this in your cart yet?

, 2016
												OUTSTANDING game.First of all, I adore indie games. I love the creativity and teamwork that comes with creating indie games, and they are my favorite genre to play and watch. I picked up this game on my queue during the Steam summer sale, but let me tell you, it's at least worth the five dollars standard price.As an avid lover of rhythm games, I was pleasantly surprised at the complexity of each level. The difficulty increased without overwhelming the player, and the spells come in a great variety that essentially allow the player to beat the game in their own style. The art style is consistent, entirely due to the fact that every visual was created by the same artist! And it's so very sweet on the eyes.Moving on to the characters, I have to say that while it is a rather short game (I finished all achievements in around 2-3 hours, after resetting my glitched game, a result of an error on my part) and thus we don't get to see much in terms of character depth or development, the characters' presence was enough to add quality and personality to the game without taking away the mystery and shock of the plot (I loved each of the Guardians and applaud the voice actors, as well as the artist, for providing such animated spirit). The ending leaves several questions unanswered, and if you're ambitious enough to get the hidden ending, you get a taste of even more secrets yet to be revealed.I couldn't put this game down. It was funny, intriguing, and the artwork and music are STELLAR!Now, to be fair, the game did have some drawbacks. I feel like the characters were a bit flat, but, if you play the game, you'll figure out why they seem to be so...scripted. It is a short game (hence the low price), but the crew that worked on it was so small! Aside from the voice actors, very few people put together a game that I will proudly call one of my all-time favorites. Iridium Studios, thank you for this masterpiece; I will cherish it for years to come.

ber 11, 2016
												Overall, I liked Before the Echo. I'm quite fond of rythm games in general (hard player on Guitar Hero, but not expert) and I liked the mix of rythm and RPG elements here.At first I wasn't much into the artstyle but I got used to it and kinda like it now. Same went for the dialogues which are a bit cheesy, especially in the beginning but then you get into the story and it's all ok. I found the story interesting and mostly went to the end of the game for that. Oh and the voiced credits is a nice little bonus ^^.As for the game mechanics, they mostly work well. You got stats to increase with stuff and level up, and spells to unlock and select for your build. The "line" selection during combats gives you control on how to spend your time and keystrokes.Though, the main negative point I have with this game lie in the game design. I started the game in Hard mode because I'm used to rythm games, it gives a little challenge and at first it was all ok. But, as after floor 3 you can't change difficulty, I regretted that choice much later when I needed to unlock more spells and couldn't because it was too hard for me (struggling with keys and controller, more used to frets). So I finished the game with only 7 of the 20+ (?) spells unlocked. And I unlocked 2 of them out of necessity for the floor 7 boss and final boss.The second complain I could make about the design of the game is about the final boss. On floor 7, once beat the boss of the level, you immediatly encounter the final boss and start the battle. There is a noticeable difficulty increase from the floor 7 boss. Therefore if you barely beat the previous boss, you can't beat the final boss and you have to go back and farm to level up and increase your stats. Also, because the damages notes are random, and in the battle the rythm of the song varies a lot, you end up in a total random fight when casting your spells and it ends up being infuriating. I lost my temper there with 20-30+ tries. I guess it's mostly because I didn't have the right spells unlocked but I was also struggling to unlock them.So, could be a bit better on some points, but overall a good and enjoyable game with a nice story to it. Liking rythm games is recommended to play this one ;)

But for just 5 bucks, it is hard to complain when you getting something unique and quite addictive, if you're into what it has to offer that is. The story is bland and the menus are simplistic but Sequence offers an intense, one-of-a-kind battle system that will leave you wanting more. It even supports the dance pad accessory!

ry 6, 2015
												As a long-time rhythm game (in this case Stepmania) player, I was really excited for Sequence. The game looked to be just the right mix between rhythm and RPG elements, with a fun soundtrack to back it up. Unfortunately the game gets a little too grindy for my taste - you can beat pretty much any encounter in the game provided that you're a high enough level. Leveling up is a chore though, and the bonus for beating an enemy skillfully isn't enough to outweigh the immense grind. A lot of the depth of the game involved simple grinding to get better levels, as later bosses had too much health and an item or a couple of levels was enough to make it easy. The grinding is really boring though as the regular creatures usually don't pose much threat. If you're a fan of rhythm games I'd recommend picking it up, but if you're new maybe give it a pass or play it on a lower difficulty. I played it on Hard because it said "for the not musically challenged," but most of the difficulty came from luck not going in my favor.

												I've been playing Before the Echo for years, and still wholeheartedly recommend it.  Several years back it was released as an Xbox Indie game called Sequence.  Controller, dancepad, and guitar support.  Not too much later it was ported to PC in all its glory.  I bought it again because, why not?  Although the voice acting and story get a lot of criticism, I love them both.  Maybe its just my kind of humor, but I find all of it both clever and charming.My only complaint about the game is depending on your dificulty of choice, you can get some harsh difficulty spikes right after you pass the point you are no longer allowed to chance your difficulty.  Be warned, but otherwise this game is loads of fun.  RPG plus Rhythm game with loads of style and witty dialogue thrown in.  Also, the creator voices the main character and honstly, I think he does a terrific job.  Well done, all around.  The game is well worth the price tag.

2, 2015
												Games like Sequence are the reason Kickstarter and the Indie Game movement exist. It's not a perfect game, not everyone is going to enjoy it and it will never receive a lot of fame and recognition. However, for the niche audience that can appreciate it, Sequence is a game like no other.The closest thing I can relate Sequence to is Puzzle Quest. The game doesn't play like Puzzle Quest but what that game did for Match-3 games, Sequence does for the rhythm genre. The base game has you traveling up a tower by fighting enemies, collecting their dropped items, and synthesising items such as keys, weapons and armor. Battles give you experience which will level up your stats while armor and weapons are equipable and can also improve your abilities. Where Sequence differs from the average dungeon crawler is that combat is played out by putting you in a rhythm system similar to StepMania, if you're using a keyboard, but with three separate boards. One board is defensive, one board is for building mana and one is for casting spells. On the first board, any notes that you miss will count as damage against you so catching them defends your HP. The second board will have a constant stream of notes. Missing them doesn't hurt you but catching them restores your mana which you need to cast spells. The last board stays dormant until you cast spells, the only way to damage your opponents. When you cast a spell, it takes mana and makes you complete a short rhythm sequence. Failing it causes the spell to fail but completing it will cast that spell. While it can be a lot to juggle at once, the game does a great job of teaching you and ramping up the difficulty slowly in order to build your skills both in game and out.The gameplay by itself is fun for a while but as the entire game is built around grinding items and EXP, it would get boring very quickly if it weren't for the well written story pushing players forward. The tone reminded me of The World Ends With You in the best possible way, but felt wholy unique. Your main character finds himself waking up in a tower with no idea how he got there. The voice of a girl named Naia tells you that you are stuck in this tower/game and you will need to make your way up 7 floors to escape so off you go. While there are some predictable moments, the story as a whole never becomes too transparent and despite a few moments when I swore I was done after one more battle, curiosity kept me pushing ever forward. The characters are all voiced as well and while none are particularly mind-blowing, it's a nice touch and the quality stayed consistent throughout. If you do find your bar set particularly high in regards to VO quality, they do have an option to turn it off as well although I doubt this will be necessary for most people.That's not to say the game isn't without it's rough spots. For a music-based game, Sequence has a surprisingly limited soundtrack of only about 10 songs that show up in battle. This means several monsters will have you playing the same songs repeatedly. Thankfully, they aren't bad and some of them I didn't mind repeating but considering each monster all but requires multiple playthroughs anyway, don't be surprised if you wind up hearing the same song 10+ times. As that suggests too, the gameplay is simply too grindy and while item drops are pretty common, it can be irritating when you need one specific item and have to fight the same monster over and over just to move forward. Finally, the song balance is a bit odd as by the end of the game, the length of the song decided more battles for me than my HP did. It felt like very artificial difficulty (you lose if the song ends before killing the enemy) and it would have been nicer to have some of the songs be just a bit longer, especially in Floor 7. Depending on your strategy, you may not have a problem with this but it showed up several times in my game.Overall, if you're looking for something different and enjoy music gameplay, Sequence is worth a shot.

ry 24, 2015
												This game is amazing. If a game that combines rhythm game and RPG appeals to you then this game would be something to look at even if that combination of genre wasn't so rare. First off to all the people who aren't scared off from thinking of potential problems or weirdness already, it's not just "let's smash these genres together". It's very functional as a rhythm game and they made that part of gameplay the "battle" portion of the RPG. You switch between "fields" to either defend against attacks, cast spells or regain mana. The balance of strength of attacks and difficulty pulling them off feels nice and natural and the game overall feels just wonderfully made. Like any RPG you might need to grind a little but just remember to pay attention to getting good equipment and good spell usage and it shouldn't get too bad. I think the only negative I can really think about gameplay is there isn't any "turn based" alternative for anyone that isn't physically capable of playing a timing based game, but for the rest of it it's good to go. Music and visual aesthetics might depend a bit on individual taste to say for sure but I personally loved both in this game.  The story is awesome too, unlike a lot of other RPG's it doesn't give you a ton of story which works since plenty of the interest comes in the mystery and uncertainty. You get just a few cutscenes every floor, long enough to enjoy the strange characters but not so long you forget you're playing a video game. Trust me there's not really any throw away characters.Saddly as much as I'd like to go on I don't know how much deeper I can dig without risking any spoilers or rambling on too much, but trust me when I say this is a unique gem of a game worth playing through to the end.

												Ever played StepMania? This game plays a lot like it, but with three different planes you can switch between, and a nice side of RPG experience point earning with an interesting story and tons of laughs. No, really. Within five seconds I was already in love with this game because of the banter between Ky and Naia. The ending isn't what you would expect, either, and will have you going ".../what" along with the characters. The music is great to groove out to, there are four difficulties for the musically (dis)inclined, and the background art is beautiful.A little caution if you're against people joking around 80% of the time and making pop culture or using memes. You aren't able to choose the songs that you can play, outside the three you're given for a level, but thankfully the songs never get annoying.All in all, it's a pretty fun game, and is well worth the $5 you pay for it. Even the credits are worth listening to.

There are some good 12+ hours of gameplay on the normal difficulty, plus some cool bonuses and optional hidden ending for the hardcore looters.For this price, it's definitely a good buy, even if you're not particularly interested in rhythm games in the first place (that's my case, and I still really enjoyed Before the Echo).
