(Floor 7 gimmick was annoying as heck though)I recently got access to my DDR pad again (I had a better (actually metal) one but the USB connector doesn't seem to work), so I tried playing the game with that (This is possible if you use AntiMicro): there weren't enough buttons and trying to press the A and B buttons to switch panes was disorienting at best since muscle memory from DDR had me keep my other foot on the center panel instead of doing anything productive, so I ended up getting a keyboard, remapping F1 to F6 as the spell keys and F9 and F10 as the pane switch keys, holding it like a guitar, and mashing the F# buttons appropriately.This worked surprisingly well overall, except my DDR pad is garbage at detecting inputs, which was frustrating. It also didn't help that my balance was skewed by holding the keyboard (Playing on the Hard difficulty, for reference, so there are a nontrivial number of notes) and the fact that I looked like a dork while jumping around with it, but still, it was reasonably fun (and good exercise too, especially since you only have your arm up to your elbow for balance).Definitely worth $1 when on sale, and definitely worth buying my first $20 steam gift card. Would recommend.

												Considering that this is a blend of rhythm games and RPGs, my two favorite genres, I don't know why it didn't catch my eye on day one. The general gameplay involves switching between three play fields - one to gain mana to cast spells, one to actually use the spells, and one to defend against enemy attacks. It's the kind of concept that must be played to get a good idea of, but let me tell you, it's great. Most of the gameplay music is by Ronald Jenkees, who I now know to be a fantastic artist. While the ending is a bit lackluster on all accounts - a tad 'what the heck?', a bit of open-endedness, even on the secret ending, and a special achievement that might or might not really bug you (I was fine with it, and rather liked it) - Sequence/Before The Echo is an indie game that you need to buy right this second. Just be ready for tons of horrible puns.

er 30, 2015
												Had this game recommended to me as a good music game hybrid, and was pleasantly surprised.  I'm not usually an RPG fan, but this game is enjoyable so far and there's no question that I'll see it through to the end.As a long-time DDR/stepmania player, I stepped quite easily into hard mode.  The charts themselves are still pretty easy for me, and I can easily get 100% while unlocking spells.  However, during regular gameplay, coordinating switching between panes with hitting notes is a new and interesting challenge.The biggest downside so far is the lack of content.  The soundtrack, while well-made, is extremely limited, and you'll end up hearing the same handful of songs over and over (so far maybe a half dozen songs in the first 4/7 floors of the tower, compared to dozens/hundreds in your average true rhythm game).  That coupled with the fact that I'm better than halfway through the game in under 4 hours suggests that this game won't have replay value.Other thoughts:- The art is somewhat low-res (720p?) and you can't change resolutions.  You can choose full screen or windowed though.  Not something I notice during gameplay, but nowadays I'd expect full HD (or preferably vector) art.- So far I've only gotten one defensive spell and it's not that powerful.  There's a huge emphasis on attack-heavily-and-occasionally-heal with not much in the way of actually defending.  Some battles you can coast through without using the defense pane much at all, so it's not equally balanced throughout.- A lot of the items/spells seem ignorable in general, unless you're a compulsive completionist like I am.- Each floor of the tower has 3 different enemy battles (each with 3 different item drops), plus a boss battle.- It's interesting that the item drop probabilities are shown, that way you can quantify how bad your luck is when grinding.  Sure, I got the 35% item in 3 of my last 4 battles, but I only got one of the 85% item that I need three of.  Haha.- The boss battles don't seem to be replayable, but they do unlock new songs when you complete them that will be used in the higher levels of battle.- Most people complaining about the name change (from "Sequence") have no idea how trademark law works, or why companies are obligated to protect their trademarks.Overall, this game is well worth that 99c sale price, but it seems like something I'll play through once and then forget about.  I absolutely love the concept, but it needs more content for sure.

												This game is basically DDR (on a controller/keyboard) mashed up with an RPG. If that sounds like heaven to you, then you're in for a good time. You battle monsters by completing sequences of notes, swapping between three different 'tracks' to attack, block, and charge up mana. The only major problem with this game is that it is *extremely* grind-y. To move past each level, you will need to craft a key, which requires collecting multiple items dropped from the monsters in that level. The monsters will only drop the items some of the time, and multiple items are usually required so you might end up fighting the same monster (and playing the same song) several times in a row. To make matters worse, crafting the items you need costs XP (meaning more battles to earn it back) and has a chance of failing (meaning even more battles to find all those items again). Playing the same song over and over again gets old very quickly.Overall, this is a good game for rhythm game fans, but be warned that it can get repetitive.

												Before the Echo is like this weird Rhythm game and rpg rolled into one. You play the game by matching Arrows in three different fields. Defense blocks attacks, There's an attack field where you need to hit all the arrows to cast spells. Then there is the mana pool where you replenish your mana for more spells. The thing is you queue your spells up on your own. So you have to either take a few hits while you get a spell off on the enemy or maybe you'll find that gap in the enemy's attack pattern. Besides that the game has a ton of other rpg elements like monster drops, item synthesis, equipment, learning new spells and more. I also enjoy the voice acting and all the snarky sarasm that goes on between the guy you play and Naia the girl over the intercom. I was really laughing at the first boss encounter poor old percival was offended by my words. Then again he was asking for it.I say pick this up if you like rhythm games and want a splash of rpg stuff to go with it.

												Puzzle Quest is to Bejeweled as Sequence is to DDR. Sequence is a dungeon crawler / RPG of sorts in which battles are done in DDR-like matches. Of course, arrows are hit with keys instead of a dancepad. The twist is that there are three different playing fields, and you have to switch between them. One regains mana as you hit notes, one blocks incoming damage when you hit the notes, and one is for casting spells. It's an interesting concept, and while it's done very well, it still seems to be amateurish. er 27, 2014
												Bit of a mixed bag, Sequence is a rhythm game about using three different playing to fight monsters.  There's the defense field in which you defend against incoming attacks by aggressors by blocking their attacks pressing the corresponding keys.  The spell field in which you cast spells with different effects such as DoT, healing, or fast recharge low damage spells.  And the mana field in which you replenish mana, which is used to cast spells, you can only have one of these fields open at a time and there is a time limit for defeating the monster, which is an interesting concept.  The monsters have a chance of dropping various items, the lower the more rare and they all give a different amount of experience. You use your experience to craft items, spell scrolls, or keys which you use to use to progress, herein lies some of the problems of the game.  It feels like a grind, just a huge grind.  You end up wasting so much time either killing the same monster over and over again to find that ONE item you need to make better gear or spells, and you can end up wasting all of that precious expereince you earned making you down on experience, although you do lose out on some items.  It just gets very very repetitive around floor four you notice none of the spells bring anything new to the table.  It doesn't help the writing isn't super compelling.  Not to mention the music is reused and the only time you feel like you're actually playing a rhythm game is when you're in the mana field, which is when the keys actually feel like they correspond to the music.  It's got cute ideas but it's riddled with flaws, it's worth checking out if you feel confident sinking money into just to get a feel for it, hey if you're into the grind and slamming on keys for 10 seconds at a time (roughly how long it takes to get your mana replensihed) then be my guest.

er 28, 2013
												A fantastic game in which all of the mechanics have been honed to perfection. The DDR Max-RPG hybrid system works flawlessly, the voice acting is top notch, and the dialogue is great. Little touches such as being able to spend experience points to increase synthesis success, having a practice mode to work on your timing, and more are all done well. The hand painted enviornments look gorgeous, and the character and enemy designs are great, although a couple of the later enemies are palette swaps of the early ones. The soundtrack is great, with several catchy songs you'll find yourself humming in the shower later. Unfortunately, the number of tracks is rather limited, and each enemy is assigned only one song, but the songs are still good enough that they don't get annoying. The only flaw I can find is that there is no free play mode, as at this point I have reached such a high level that even the hardest battles only take around thirty seconds to win. Still, its hard to fault a game for not letting you replay it enough, so I'll conclude by saying that this is the single best indie title I have had the pleasure of playing on Steam. A fantastic game that should be enjoyed by all.

												DDR/Frequency/Amplitude with an RPG twist. If you have ever been a fan of rhythm games, particularly those by Harmonix, you (hopefully) have come across the Frequency/Amplitude series. With its rapid track-switching gameplay, it was a unique and underappreciated entry in gaming history. Now, Sequence takes the track switching mechanic, applies simple DDR-style controls, and turns it into a monster-fighting RPG. It might sound crazy, but this is probably one of the best genre hybrids since Puzzle Fighter or Bust-a Move.

, 2012
												Here's a strange melding of RPG and rhythm game that shouldn't work as well as it does.  Though I believe the game would be a hard sell to most players based on a description of its gameplay, I also think that's a shame.  Sequence is a wholely unique and worthwhile experience.Calling Sequence a role-playing game is accurate but also potentially misleading: RPG elements like experience gathering and equipment crafting are a substantial part of gameplay, but, outside of rhythm sections, you'll only be navigating through menus.  There is no exploration and very little to do outside of rhythm battles and item creation.  While this sounds shallow (and perhaps, on the surface, smacks of dumbed-down, "casual" game design) , there's plenty to do thanks to the clever design and balancing of Sequence's underlying mechanics.  The music is great, too! (Though I do wish there was more of it.)Highly recommended for rhythm fans.

												I can recommend this game to anyone who likes rhythm games. They did a good job at implementing RPG elements into the genre and wrapped everything up in a surprisingly decent story. You can play this with a keyboard, but I found it a bit easier to play with a controller.So basically you "fight" yourself through a tower with seven floors and their guardians, and by fighting I mean you press directional arrows in three different windows to either defend yourself, regenerate mana or cast spells. If you're bad with coordination you might have trouble on the higher floors as switching quickly between the windows will become mandatory.My two major gripes with the game are a lack of different soundtracks early on (luckily there will be more variety later on, and some of the soundtracks are amazing) and incredibly frustrating RNG at times. Both item drops and crafting items are based on a percentage, the latter costing experience which makes failing a little more frustrating. If you want to get everything, you WILL have to grind a bit. Other than that, I found it overall enjoyable and enticing.

ry 17, 2016
												This game's Very Positive rating at the time of this review really boggles my mind. It's not that the game is bad, rather that its an idea who's implementation seems inherently flawed.The base mechanic of the game is the traditional "press one or more of the 4 directions on the beat as instructed". However, the twist is that you have three panels of arrows to rotate between and timing your presses correctly on them has different effects. There's your mana regen panel where each correct press earns you a little mana to cast spells. There's another that represents spellcasting where successfully landing a series of presses will cast a spell (more on this later). The last one represents defense where a sequence of arrows represents the enemy's attack; if you miss any here you take damage.The problem is that the defense panel's arrows (i.e. the enemy's attacks) occur at random, but you have to manually trigger your spellcast sequences. You may already see the issue here: you build mana, cast an attack spell, and arrows start to fall in the spell cast panel and defense panel simultaneously. The game's prescribed cure for this is to constantly keep up a "barrier" spell which effectively mutes the enemy. So the game requires you to continually recast this barrier spell so that you can actually cast the spells you want in between each barrier cast. In my opinion this is a kludge of a game mechanic. You get involved with a whole lot of busy work just to occasionally do something meaningful. Perhaps it all gets a bit smoother with some practice, but whats to engage you enough to want to get that good?I found a majority of the music to be ignorable at best. I've enjoyed some of Ronald Jenkees' music, but what's offered here I'd be reluctant to classify as even B-side music. The dialog is atrocious, the story is insignificant, and the graphics are the kind of crappy animatics that have now become standard fair in a sea of indie game dev mediocrity. The game would be perfectly suited for two hands on the keyboard, but I was forced into using a controller. (Oh I hope this wasn't just because I had a controller plugged into my PC; I'm not going back!)Perhaps worst yet is that the game devolves into a grind as each enemy you face has the chance to drop (at most?) one of three items of increasingly rarer chances to drop. You can face an enemy multiple times (enjoying the same music each time!) to get all items from an enemy. Why? Did the game need a time sink like this? Again, its more poor game design that not only contributes nothing fun, but actually contributes frustration.I really wanted to like this game. I had it on my wishlist as soon as it was released and bought it while it was still named Sequence. Despite the game's somewhat novel concept, it seems like the developer tried to throw a hodge-podge of ideas and twists at the rhythm genre, but just ended up with an overly-complicated and unfun mess.Unless you're some kind of rhythm game fanatic, skip this one. 6/10

												A fantastic game in which all of the mechanics have been honed to perfection. The DDR Max-RPG hybrid system works flawlessly, the voice acting is top notch, and the dialogue is great. Little touches such as being able to spend experience points to increase synthesis success, having a practice mode to work on your timing, and more are all done well. The hand painted enviornments look gorgeous, and the character and enemy designs are great, although a couple of the later enemies are palette swaps of the early ones. The soundtrack is great, with several catchy songs you'll find yourself humming in the shower later. Unfortunately, the number of tracks is rather limited, and each enemy is assigned only one song, but the songs are still good enough that they don't get annoying. The only flaw I can find is that there is no free play mode, as at this point I have reached such a high level that even the hardest battles only take around thirty seconds to win. Still, its hard to fault a game for not letting you replay it enough, so I'll conclude by saying that this is the single best indie title I have had the pleasure of playing on Steam. A fantastic game that should be enjoyed by all.

y 1, 2012
												Rhythm game meets old-school turn-based RPG. This is every bit as peculiar as it sounds. The music is slick, much of it licensed from capable hands such as the wonderful Ronald Jenkees, and the gameplay can be quite punishing on higher difficulty levels. I would recommend playing this game witha controller, and indeed have not checked if it is possible (or enjoyable) without.You'll be switching between three sets of scrolling DDR style arrows: one for incoming damage that is blocked by accurate hits, another (typically containing the most difficult pieces of the song) recharges your Mana pool on accurate hits, and a third for spells. Spells are cast with the right analog stick, which (after a delay) sends down a specific rhythmic snippet that changes it's tempo to fit the current song (the specific direction of arrows changes every time you cast, and the difficulty level also changes the spells, making the more complicated versions of the same basic rhytmic idea). The game has you madly flying between these screens to defeat enemies before the song ends--it's one wierd, wild ride and it's well worth it. Battles are tense and fascinating, and there's a lot of room for varied play styles in your spell collection of choice as well as a lot of room for growth within the broad difficulty span. There's even a practice mode where you can just play through the full songs in a more standard rhthym game format. Highly recommended.

r 3, 2016
												9/10An interesting blend of RPG and rhythm game that works incredibly well.Before the Echo is a game that combines the usual mechanics from rhythm games, where you have to press keys/buttons with the precise timing according to the music played, with elements from RPG games - leveling up, acquiring new gear, crafting, etc. And it does so very well. Basically, you have 3 screens - Attack, Defense and Mana. You use the Mana screen to recover Mana spent, the Attack screen to cast spells and the Defense screen to block incoming enemy attacks. To advance through the game, the player needs to know how to administer all three screens, changing between them whenever needed and using the proper timing to cast spells so that they're not cast at the same time an enemy attack is coming. The player can then learn new spells with varied effects like damage, damage over time, healing, creating a protective barrier, etc. The stronger the spell, the harder it is to cast it. Items improve the character's stats, making the character cause more damage, take less damage, recover more Mana, etc. Bosses have special abilities of their own that makes the battle harder.At first, the story seems to be overly simplistic, but as the game develops and the story unfolds, it's revealed that there's a lot more to it. Characters are interesting and there is character development throughout the story and the voice acting is very well done.For those who like a challenge, the game has four difficulty levels, with the hardest difficulty being for those lovers of rhythm games. The easiest difficulty still presents some challenge at later levels. (I actually had to reduce the difficulty to Easy for the last boss)And, of course, the soundtrack - truly amazing. I would have expected a good soundtrack for a game that is heavily based on music, but even then, it surpassed my expectations.Highly recommended.

												As someone who's been playing Dance Dance Revolution emulators on PC since 2003, I drooled at the chance to try this.  I was not disappointed.  In the same way that Puzzle Quest was a role-playing adventure using Bejeweled as its combat system, Sequence is a fun, genuinely hilarious quest that has you playing DDR to represent combat.  This is a lot more creative than it sounds.  You're faced with three streams of arrows; one for offense, one for defense, and one for regaining mana used to fuel your attacks.  Constantly shifting between streams, organizing your list of spells, and seeking out rare materials for crafting new gear is made even more fun by the top quality music, great voice acting, and a script that is much funnier than you'd ever expect.  The $5 price is yet another reason you should add this to your collection.  Don't pass this up.

												DDR/Frequency/Amplitude with an RPG twist. If you have ever been a fan of rhythm games, particularly those by Harmonix, you (hopefully) have come across the Frequency/Amplitude series. With its rapid track-switching gameplay, it was a unique and underappreciated entry in gaming history. Now, Sequence takes the track switching mechanic, applies simple DDR-style controls, and turns it into a monster-fighting RPG. It might sound crazy, but this is probably one of the best genre hybrids since Puzzle Fighter or Bust-a Move.

												Before the Echo is like this weird Rhythm game and rpg rolled into one. You play the game by matching Arrows in three different fields. Defense blocks attacks, There's an attack field where you need to hit all the arrows to cast spells. Then there is the mana pool where you replenish your mana for more spells. The thing is you queue your spells up on your own. So you have to either take a few hits while you get a spell off on the enemy or maybe you'll find that gap in the enemy's attack pattern. Besides that the game has a ton of other rpg elements like monster drops, item synthesis, equipment, learning new spells and more. I also enjoy the voice acting and all the snarky sarasm that goes on between the guy you play and Naia the girl over the intercom. I was really laughing at the first boss encounter poor old percival was offended by my words. Then again he was asking for it.I say pick this up if you like rhythm games and want a splash of rpg stuff to go with it.

, 2015
												I loved rhythm games and RPGs while growing up. I tried twice, a couple years apart, but this game just couldn't hold my interest.It's not fun to grind. It's especially not fun when it means playing the same song over and over, with nothing new happening. Most of the non-gameplay actions you can take require wagering experience points -- academically, the mechanic is really interesting...but gameplay-wise, it's just frustrating to spend massive amounts of experience points on this.The characters, at least through as much of the game as I saw, were just cringey. It's like Twilight for boys -- a totally non-special guy randomly ends up in a magical world where a woman with a sexy voice flirts with him. I'm looking for something a little more interesting than sarcasm. I don't need an elitist lesson in how everyone but the dev pronounces "mana" wrong -- I'm sure there's an audience that resonates with, but it isn't me.The actual gameplay is not terrible, and involves rotating through 3 DDR-style tracks -- one to defend, one to regenerate mana, and one to cast spells. Again, it's academically interesting, but gameplay-wise, it's just kind of infuriating to constantly be shown the opportunity cost of the choosing the track you're currently on.So maybe that's my gripe -- the game always made me feel like I wasn't doing what I should be doing. The game wants me to take risks with my EXP wagering and to not care about the other tracks during gameplay, but my personality doesn't let me switch into that mode. My personality isn't changing, the game isn't changing, and we're just not a match. If you're not like me, this might be the game for you!

												The boring prequel to the much more interesting "There Came an Echo".  The game plays much like StepMania (DDR without the dancing) although there is an intersting field switch mechanic which you need to exploit to clear the stages.  Alot of odd design decisions went into this game; spend your experince to maybe get an item, craft required items in order to progress the stage, challenge the same stage over and over in hopes of getting key components.  It all adds up to repetitively grinding the same monsters on the same handful of songs over and over in order to progress.  I can only imagine these were added to help artifically increase the length of the game, which would otherwise be extremely short, which leads me into my major issue with the game; the writing.Writing is an issue which it's much better successor shares, everyone is so contrived in following along with the plotline, In this iteration, the protaginist and the supporting heroine are set up as antagonists, but engage in half hearted bickering until events contrive to have the hero off rescuing her a couple in game hours after their intitial meeting; what changed to reconcile these two advesaries?  A couple of passing comments wich imply the possibly the heroine is not 100% commited to organization which is forcing the hero to risk his life.  If only it was that easy for me to reconcile with my enemies.  The story climax involves a forced moral objection to something which, when you think about it, isn't all that bad, which has the hero vowing to commit his life to destroying those responsible and taking on substatial personal risk in the interium.  This isn't a crusader of justice, it's suposedly a VERY bright college kid caught up in a risky mis-adventure.  In real life, 10 of 10 of such kids would not tell the head of a powerful multinational organization which managed to abduct them and spirt them away to tower of death, that not only will you not forgive them, you'll make it your life's work to destroy them for the crime of  setting you up on a blind date

er 30, 2015
												Had this game recommended to me as a good music game hybrid, and was pleasantly surprised.  I'm not usually an RPG fan, but this game is enjoyable so far and there's no question that I'll see it through to the end.As a long-time DDR/stepmania player, I stepped quite easily into hard mode.  The charts themselves are still pretty easy for me, and I can easily get 100% while unlocking spells.  However, during regular gameplay, coordinating switching between panes with hitting notes is a new and interesting challenge.The biggest downside so far is the lack of content.  The soundtrack, while well-made, is extremely limited, and you'll end up hearing the same handful of songs over and over (so far maybe a half dozen songs in the first 4/7 floors of the tower, compared to dozens/hundreds in your average true rhythm game).  That coupled with the fact that I'm better than halfway through the game in under 4 hours suggests that this game won't have replay value.Other thoughts:- The art is somewhat low-res (720p?) and you can't change resolutions.  You can choose full screen or windowed though.  Not something I notice during gameplay, but nowadays I'd expect full HD (or preferably vector) art.- So far I've only gotten one defensive spell and it's not that powerful.  There's a huge emphasis on attack-heavily-and-occasionally-heal with not much in the way of actually defending.  Some battles you can coast through without using the defense pane much at all, so it's not equally balanced throughout.- A lot of the items/spells seem ignorable in general, unless you're a compulsive completionist like I am.- Each floor of the tower has 3 different enemy battles (each with 3 different item drops), plus a boss battle.- It's interesting that the item drop probabilities are shown, that way you can quantify how bad your luck is when grinding.  Sure, I got the 35% item in 3 of my last 4 battles, but I only got one of the 85% item that I need three of.  Haha.- The boss battles don't seem to be replayable, but they do unlock new songs when you complete them that will be used in the higher levels of battle.- Most people complaining about the name change (from "Sequence") have no idea how trademark law works, or why companies are obligated to protect their trademarks.Overall, this game is well worth that 99c sale price, but it seems like something I'll play through once and then forget about.  I absolutely love the concept, but it needs more content for sure.

, 2016
												OUTSTANDING game.First of all, I adore indie games. I love the creativity and teamwork that comes with creating indie games, and they are my favorite genre to play and watch. I picked up this game on my queue during the Steam summer sale, but let me tell you, it's at least worth the five dollars standard price.As an avid lover of rhythm games, I was pleasantly surprised at the complexity of each level. The difficulty increased without overwhelming the player, and the spells come in a great variety that essentially allow the player to beat the game in their own style. The art style is consistent, entirely due to the fact that every visual was created by the same artist! And it's so very sweet on the eyes.Moving on to the characters, I have to say that while it is a rather short game (I finished all achievements in around 2-3 hours, after resetting my glitched game, a result of an error on my part) and thus we don't get to see much in terms of character depth or development, the characters' presence was enough to add quality and personality to the game without taking away the mystery and shock of the plot (I loved each of the Guardians and applaud the voice actors, as well as the artist, for providing such animated spirit). The ending leaves several questions unanswered, and if you're ambitious enough to get the hidden ending, you get a taste of even more secrets yet to be revealed.I couldn't put this game down. It was funny, intriguing, and the artwork and music are STELLAR!Now, to be fair, the game did have some drawbacks. I feel like the characters were a bit flat, but, if you play the game, you'll figure out why they seem to be so...scripted. It is a short game (hence the low price), but the crew that worked on it was so small! Aside from the voice actors, very few people put together a game that I will proudly call one of my all-time favorites. Iridium Studios, thank you for this masterpiece; I will cherish it for years to come.

												Haven't finished yet, but I truly love the style, gameplay, concept, and mechanics of the game!Imagine an RPG style "guitar hero like" rhythm game. Got you hooked yet? Simply put, the player switches between 3 "fields" or screens (Defence, Spell, and Mana) while in game as arrows move down in each field. There's a great deal of multitasking involved because of casting spells, defending yourself, and gaining mana.You win by draining the opponent's HP to 0 by casting damaging spells, but you can lose by losing all of your health or by not winning by the end of the song. It's a great game that keeps you on your toes and equipping the right spells. That being said, don't feel as though there are "wrong" or "right" spells to use. Some are better for certain levels or battles, but I've been able to use the spells that fit my playstyle. Before the Echo is a great game for people who love RPGs but may not have all the time in the world to spend 60+ hours in.

ry 24, 2015
												This game is amazing. If a game that combines rhythm game and RPG appeals to you then this game would be something to look at even if that combination of genre wasn't so rare. First off to all the people who aren't scared off from thinking of potential problems or weirdness already, it's not just "let's smash these genres together". It's very functional as a rhythm game and they made that part of gameplay the "battle" portion of the RPG. You switch between "fields" to either defend against attacks, cast spells or regain mana. The balance of strength of attacks and difficulty pulling them off feels nice and natural and the game overall feels just wonderfully made. Like any RPG you might need to grind a little but just remember to pay attention to getting good equipment and good spell usage and it shouldn't get too bad. I think the only negative I can really think about gameplay is there isn't any "turn based" alternative for anyone that isn't physically capable of playing a timing based game, but for the rest of it it's good to go. Music and visual aesthetics might depend a bit on individual taste to say for sure but I personally loved both in this game.  The story is awesome too, unlike a lot of other RPG's it doesn't give you a ton of story which works since plenty of the interest comes in the mystery and uncertainty. You get just a few cutscenes every floor, long enough to enjoy the strange characters but not so long you forget you're playing a video game. Trust me there's not really any throw away characters.Saddly as much as I'd like to go on I don't know how much deeper I can dig without risking any spoilers or rambling on too much, but trust me when I say this is a unique gem of a game worth playing through to the end.

er 27, 2014
												Bit of a mixed bag, Sequence is a rhythm game about using three different playing to fight monsters.  There's the defense field in which you defend against incoming attacks by aggressors by blocking their attacks pressing the corresponding keys.  The spell field in which you cast spells with different effects such as DoT, healing, or fast recharge low damage spells.  And the mana field in which you replenish mana, which is used to cast spells, you can only have one of these fields open at a time and there is a time limit for defeating the monster, which is an interesting concept.  The monsters have a chance of dropping various items, the lower the more rare and they all give a different amount of experience. You use your experience to craft items, spell scrolls, or keys which you use to use to progress, herein lies some of the problems of the game.  It feels like a grind, just a huge grind.  You end up wasting so much time either killing the same monster over and over again to find that ONE item you need to make better gear or spells, and you can end up wasting all of that precious expereince you earned making you down on experience, although you do lose out on some items.  It just gets very very repetitive around floor four you notice none of the spells bring anything new to the table.  It doesn't help the writing isn't super compelling.  Not to mention the music is reused and the only time you feel like you're actually playing a rhythm game is when you're in the mana field, which is when the keys actually feel like they correspond to the music.  It's got cute ideas but it's riddled with flaws, it's worth checking out if you feel confident sinking money into just to get a feel for it, hey if you're into the grind and slamming on keys for 10 seconds at a time (roughly how long it takes to get your mana replensihed) then be my guest.

14, 2015
												This game is excellent. Normally, RPGs and music games both face issues, but I can't readily see them in this title. It took the gameplay of Rockband: Unplugged for the PSP and made it actually functional, and into an intuitive battle system. The RPG elements, with the ability to gain and lose levels as you spend time bettering your character, made character building interesting and every upgrade felt impactful. The voice acting was well done too, though similarly with There Came an Echo the character development was not endearing, focused too much on antagonistic dialouge rather than meaningful trait building. Still, however, you can skip these scenes so you can get away from that as much as possible. The game itself, I'll warn, has little replay value. There's no software to add custom tracks like in Audiosurf, the music gets used on multiple levels and, given you are grinding, you get to hear the songs over and over again. If the music was bad, this would have been worse of an issue but I can't honestly say that the songs were terrible and didn't go so far as to play abrasive music from Dubstep, etc. Other things I'd change would be additions of things like local PvP, clearer labeling on the spell circle to tell which spell was which and what numbers corresponded to which slice of the circle, and more than seven levels/three battle senarios per level.  All in all it is a fun game. For 5$, it has about as much content as you'd expect and with as polished as it looks, sounds, and feels I can't recommend it enough.

er 27, 2011
												This game is a cross between Dance Dance Revolution / Stepmania and Puzzle Quest.If you reacted to that sentence with "hey that sounds cool," this game is for you. Not certain? Still worth a look.Playable with the keyboard, a gamepad, or a dance pad (which I really want to try one of these days), the basic gist of the gameplay is hitting arrows in time with a beat a la DDR. For the Puzzle Quest influence, this has an RPG story where you beat monsters to collect items and proceed up a tower. You flip between three "boards": one board's arrows are attacks aimed at you, and clearing the arrow defends against the attack; one board will regenerate your mana; a third board is active when you cast a spell, and nailing that sequence means your spell succeeds.The dialogue is refreshingly snarky, and fully voice-acted.The all-important question: how's the music? Very good, and there's a solid variety too. At least, variety within the style - they're all going to be a bit dancy-technoey.

er 26, 2013
												Brilliant mix of RPG and... rhythm game?!Dance Dance Revolution style games have always seemed a little dodgy on a control pad, but Sequence amps up the difficulty by introducing three separate fields -- defense (missed notes hurt you), spells (getting all notes in a spell casts it) and mana (a constant stream; each note hit gives +2 mana).Monsters drop various items, which can be crafted into new spells, weapons, armour, accessories, and the key required to face that floor's miniboss. My biggest issue with the game, as it happens, is that the various random events -- random drops, percentage to succeed/fail at crafting -- can be frustrating when luck is not on your side. You might find yourself fighting the same monster a dozen times before getting a key item supposedly dropped in 42% of battles.But the art is good and the writing is great, even if the story does fizzle out somewhat as it becomes more serious. The item descriptions are especially fun; with very few exceptions they are awful, awful puns. (An example off the top of my head is the Lightwave Sword: "Also Lightparticle Sword." The description for Polish Remover is "Hitler".)

, 2016
												OUTSTANDING game.First of all, I adore indie games. I love the creativity and teamwork that comes with creating indie games, and they are my favorite genre to play and watch. I picked up this game on my queue during the Steam summer sale, but let me tell you, it's at least worth the five dollars standard price.As an avid lover of rhythm games, I was pleasantly surprised at the complexity of each level. The difficulty increased without overwhelming the player, and the spells come in a great variety that essentially allow the player to beat the game in their own style. The art style is consistent, entirely due to the fact that every visual was created by the same artist! And it's so very sweet on the eyes.Moving on to the characters, I have to say that while it is a rather short game (I finished all achievements in around 2-3 hours, after resetting my glitched game, a result of an error on my part) and thus we don't get to see much in terms of character depth or development, the characters' presence was enough to add quality and personality to the game without taking away the mystery and shock of the plot (I loved each of the Guardians and applaud the voice actors, as well as the artist, for providing such animated spirit). The ending leaves several questions unanswered, and if you're ambitious enough to get the hidden ending, you get a taste of even more secrets yet to be revealed.I couldn't put this game down. It was funny, intriguing, and the artwork and music are STELLAR!Now, to be fair, the game did have some drawbacks. I feel like the characters were a bit flat, but, if you play the game, you'll figure out why they seem to be so...scripted. It is a short game (hence the low price), but the crew that worked on it was so small! Aside from the voice actors, very few people put together a game that I will proudly call one of my all-time favorites. Iridium Studios, thank you for this masterpiece; I will cherish it for years to come.

er 29, 2016
												I went into this game fully knowing it was a DDR game. Being mediocre at it, i thought that it would be a simple 2 maybe 3 hours to finish this.Now, what i did not expect was the engaging storyline, the funny banter and the relationships that develop. If you are a storyline kind of person and can do so-so in stepmania, i would encourage you to give this a go. While "grinding" for levels is a thing in this game, you'll notice that you would do the same in any DDR / stepmania type of game. Watch yourself get better as you aim for that perfect all the while gaining more power (by leveling) and actual skill of both memory and reflexes.All in all, i find this to be my hidden gem. Simple gameplay, GREAT storyline and above all memorable chracters.
